title: What are the differences between philosophies of Socrates and Plato? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is very difficult if not impossible to answer. Since Socrates did not actually write down his philosophy, (it is recorded by others, especially Plato) we don’t actually know where Socrates ends and Plato begins. A reasonable conjecture is that Plato’s early Socratic dialogues such as Euphythro, Apology, and Phaedo, probably best represent the words and philosophy of Socrates himself. Above all Socrates seems interested in getting people to think for themselves, and challenging peoples own ignorance. Starting with the middle to late dialogues, such as The Republic and Timaeus, the “argumentative” Socrates we had in earlier dialogues turns into more of a mouthpiece for specific metaphysical and ontological theories, especially what has become known as the theory of the forms. This is probably where Plato begins to assert his own thought. However, the delineation above is really conjecture. We have no hard evidence to go on.
